A Taste of South Africa - The Bunny Chow A Taste of South Africa - The Bunny Chow 0 
With restaurants in India opening up to world cuisines, there seems to be a massive culinary import of some stellar dishes from across the globe. Have you ever come across the term 'Bunny Chow'? Well, it's the most talked about South African delicacy in town these days! 
So what is the bunny chow? Simply put, it's the South African version of a burger, the country's offering to the world of fast food! Traditionally, it's a hollowed out loaf of bread filled in with some or the other curry. And the wonderful thing about the new restaurants of the India are that you don't need to become a businessperson or a graduate from tourism courses in India travelling the world over to get a taste of global cuisines. If you want to try out a bunny chow, all you need to do is drop by at the closest South African joint. Or, you could cook it right at home, here's how! In a large pan, heat 1⁄2 cup oil and then fry 1 star anise, 1 cinnamon stick, 3 whole cardamom pods, 1⁄2 teaspoon fennel seed, 1⁄2 teaspoon cumin seed, along with 1 chopped onion. Next, add 3 tablespoons garam masala, 1 teaspoon ground coriander seeds, 1 teaspoon ground cayenne pepper, and 2 teaspoons turmeric. Stir fry the ingredients until the spices appear to stick to the base of the pan. At this point, add 2 chopped tomatoes and stir till the ingredients are cooked well. Now, throw in 2 pounds of cubed lamb or beef, as per your choice. Add 4 chopped garlic cloves, 2 teaspoons ground ginger and 6 curry leaves to the meat and gravy. After a while of simmering, add 2 chopped potatoes and a bit of water. Let the contents of the pan simmer until the meat is tender. 
Voila, you've now cooked the curry that goes into the bunny chow! Now, for preparing the bread: Slice a solid rectangular loaf of bread into as many pieces as required, depending on the size you want. Cut off the top and hollow out the insides of the loaf, keeping the sides and bottom strong and sturdy. It should be hard enough to support the gravy, a hotel management college graduate would advice! Pour in the gravy, and put the top that you had previously cut off back on. 
Now all you've got to do is bite into this succulent delight and savour the flavours of some authentic South African cuisine!
